title: Cat. 145  Firelight, 1896
publication_title: The Lithographs of James McNeill Whistler: The Digital Edition

Levy: 151  
Transfer lithograph, drawn on white transfer paper with a grained-stone texture  
Ink color: black  
Signature: printed butterfly, center right  
One state; image size: 191 × 149 mm  
Number of impressions listed by Way: 15  
Printer: Way  
Watermarks: 2, 120­22, 151, 258, 296, 297, 309  
Stone: erased on 28 March 1904  
Whistler-Way Letters: apps. III.2, V.1  
Selected Literature: Way (1903), p. 19; Way and Dennis (1903), p. 87; Duret (1904), p. 125; Pennell and Pennell (1908), vol. 2, p. 169; Way (1912), pp. 123–24  
Lifetime Exhibitions: London 1895–96 (in 2d ed. of catalogue only; no. 71); New York 1898 (no. 353); Chicago 1900b (no. 95, as Firelight [Mrs. Pennel])

Elizabeth Pennell (1855–1936), a writer by profession, was two years her husband’s senior and would have been forty-one when Whistler drew this portrait in January 1896. In their 1908 biography of the artist, the Pennells recalled how the artist had drawn their portraits during afternoon visits to their lodgings on Buckingham Street. Firelight was singled out: “Whistler made four portraits of J. [cat. 141, cat. 142, cat. 143, and cat. 144] and one of E., each the work of an afternoon. He worked on into the darkness, especially in the portrait of E., done while the firelight flickered on her face and on his paper.” Always fascinated by the effects of firelight, Whistler had devoted several recent lithographs to the depiction of a Lyme Regis blacksmith shop illuminated by furnace light (cat. 125, cat. 127, and cat. 128). In his portraits of the Pennells, as in the smithy images of October 1895, he utilized networks of parallel lines to build the dramatic, flickering shadows surrounding his sitters.

Whistler wrote an apologetic dedication on the impression of Firelight that he gave to the Pennells (now in the Library of Congress, Washington, D.C., Pennell Collection). Nevertheless, he must have been satisfied with the image, for it was one of five lithographs that he added to the Fine Art Society’s exhibition in late January 1896, when the retrospective had already been underway for over a month.

There was no posthumous edition of this lithograph. Rosalind Birnie Philip’s personal animosity toward the Pennells prompted her to order Goulding to erase this stone (see also cat. 143, cat. 144, and cat. 145).

Chicago: AIC, ivory laid paper (332 × 210 mm), signed; MWC, cream laid paper (282 × 226 mm), signed; SC, cream Japanese paper (287 × 220 mm). Glasgow: HAG (5), cream laid paper (287 × 231 mm), signed; cream laid paper (218 × 186 mm); cream laid paper (217 × 198 mm); cream Japanese paper (288 × 222 mm); cream Japanese paper (287 × 220 mm). London: BM, cream laid paper (283 × 230 mm). Washington: FGA, cream laid paper (294 × 207 mm), signed; LC, ivory laid paper (295 × 215 mm), signed and inscribed, in Whistler’s hand, To / Mr. Joseph Pennell / with sincere apologies; NGA, cream laid paper (284 × 230 mm), signed.

Remarks: Other impressions are found in Ann Arbor, UMMA; Boston, BPL (2); Cambridge, Mass., FAM; Cleveland, CMA; and New York, MMA (2) and NYPL.  
Nesta R. Spink, Harriet K. Stratis, Martha Tedeschi
